subject: RE: [junit] Testing API where order in which methods are invoked matters
msgSnippet: ... I don t see why it s too hard to do that:  the framework will always guarantee that the methods are invoked in the right order and that dependent methods
messageBody:
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
> Behalf Of Chris Dollin

> Yes, the methods in your test class are not (necessarily)
> called in any particular order. This is a feature. Each test
> method should be unrelated to the others - otherwise it's too
> hard to eg move them around for greater expressivity, call
> only the failing when when you want to isolate a problem, &co.

I don't see why it's too hard to do that: the framework will always
guarantee that the methods are invoked in the right order and that dependent
methods will always be invoked before.

Anyway, the short answer to the original question is that ordering testing
methods is not covered by unit testing, and if you want to do this, you are
probably doing more than unit testing (and you should therefore use
http://testng.org :-)).

> For (b) I'd start by fixing the `connect` problem: if nothing
> can be done withotu a connection, I'd have a more
> factory-like object with a `connect` method; calling this
> delivers a connected object.

If this object is expensive to get, it would be nice to save it in-between
invocations, which brings us back to maintaining state and ordering methods.
